comments.body: breadcrumb to where this value ends up
newline
Add a paragraph before this, something like "A message to show when the dropdown is disabled."
fyi @HansMuller
what i find weird about this approach is that it's asymmetrical. Why do we clamp at zero but not at some equivalent large offset?
Remove extra blank line.
Done.
What do you bet someone reports a typo for "Free"? :-)
I was hoping someone would: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Free_Four

I have been trying get my commas straight per this madness: https://www.grammarly.com/blog/comma/

I believe this is an example of "Comma Between Correlative Conjunctions". The comma isn't needed.
English grammar is so broken. At least I learned something today!
Blah blah blah "Comma Between Correlative Conjunctions" :-)
This might be a little clearer as: `... widget.style.fontSize ?? Theme.of(context)...`
What if onChanged is null? Are we missing a test?
Since onChanged is handled like this `onChanged: onChanged==null? null : field.didChange(value)`. I guess `onChanged` won't be null here(in didChange).
As far as I understand, this makes sense because `field.didChange` is only ever called when `onChanged` is not `null`... although reading the logic at first glance was somewhat confusing.
Sounds good. To prove that we're expecting onChanged != null here, please assert as much.
Done

Sorry, I hadn't noticed this before: why are we creating all of these fields? These parameters are all just getting passed along to the super call; there doesn't seem to be any need to make them fields of DropDownButtonFormField.
Sorry @HansMuller , couldn't get you. If we donot create those fields, how are we going to pass parameteres from DropdownButtonFormField to DropdownButton and FormField. ðŸ˜•

I think what he means here is that you can just do: 
```
    Widget disabledHint,
    int elevation = 8,
    // rest of properties
    double iconSize = 24.0,
    bool isDense = false,
    bool isExpanded = false,
```
and remove all of the corresponding properties on `DropdownButtonFormField` itself. If `DropdownButtonFormField` is not directly using any of these properties and they're just being passed down to `DropdownButton`, then there's no need to define them here.
If that's possible, that helps us avoid duplicating the properties, as well as having to template out the docs as you already have.
That's right: all of the new values are being passed along via the `super()` call, there's no need to squirrel them away in this class.
@HansMuller @shihaohong Is this ok ?

comments.body:
Yes, this is my big question and probably where I struggled the most: By reading the spec, it seemed like many of these alt-texts were actually not necessary to the content and I was using it more as an "Accessibility Label" for people using screenreaders so they knew the image being displayed was basically what was described in the paragraph above.

Following [this portion of the spec](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/images.html#a-graphical-representation-of-some-of-the-surrounding-text), it seemed the best thing to do in these cases is simply remove the alt-text, so that's what I've done -- often providing a more thorough explanation in the paragraph above.

It felt a bit strange, but that was my best attempt at complying with the spec. Would certainly love input on these changes, @Hixie!

I am inclined to think it is okay since it seems to be the prevailing pattern in the codebase.  
If not, we can always return and update. ðŸ™‚
It seems like we could remove the `item` property since it isn't used anywhere except in `super`.
It's used by _DropdownMenuState to look up the menu item's value.
these helper methods are really slick
nit: "r" comes before "w", no?
Good point; reordered.
NICE. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Free_Four
Is it worth mentioning here that if the preferred menu height is too tall for the screen and `itemHeights = null`, the scroll offset will not be properly set and always be at zero?
Yes, sadly yes. Updated the doc to explain this.
It would be helpful to make the same change in the sample code.
will instead be displayed => will be displayed instead

This shouldn't be called from build. I am surprised that this is actually working and doesn't throw an "setState during build is illegal" exception.

Can you not just check in the didChangeMetrics if the orientation has changed from the last time and if it did remove the route there?

Actually, looks like we have special code in place to allow removing an overlay (like this dropdown route) during build: https://github.com/flutter/flutter/blame/166d422b05e69ea140fcdc8968282b883aad0af5/packages/flutter/lib/src/widgets/overlay.dart#L128

@Hixie Do you know why we allow this? (you added the code :P)
Is this addition of a border radius intentional? Is there something about the focus changes that needs a rounded rect? Or did this get moved from somewhere else that I missed?

Yes, it's intentional: there's no spec for this, so I'm emulating the other defaults for highlights.  It didn't get moved from anywhere because it didn't exist before, since we couldn't focus this component.

comments.body: Probably not critical, but this does mean that non-web versions of the app will have this taking up memory, right?
Yes, I guess so: it's not a lot though, since it's static.  I'll make it predicated on `kIsWeb` too and it'll take up less space then.
Actually, since it's a private static, and all uses are within `if (kIsWeb){}` blocks that will be elided, I'll bet it disappears entirely on non-web platforms.
NICE
Somewhere in the DropdownButton doc string should mention how and when to use dropdownColor
nit: this most probably not have any difference, but semantically you should call the `onTap()` first before popping the page I think.
I realize that we've been doing this all-along. I wish that InputDecorator computed the defaults.
Yeah, and I wish I could access the value of `this.decoration` in a constructor, so I wouldn't have to compute the value twice.
Although maybe I misunderstood your comment: did you want a change here?
Just an observation, sorry about the confusion.

This appears to just be a compact rewrite of the previous, although I'll be pleased to hear that I'm missing something :-). 

What is the flaw that we're correcting in this PR?
We should explicit the type of the specified list so that different types of elements can be added again later.

I had to diagram this out before I understood the change. Essentially, when `widget.selectedItemBuilder != null`, it's now `List<Widget>.from(widget.selectedItemBuilder!(context))` instead of `widget.selectedItemBuilder!(context)`, which explicitly types the list to be a list of `Widget`s
Ditto

It seems reasonable to make this default true (Text,Elevated,OutlinedButton also make it true by default). The API doc should say as much without implying that the property is default false; like: By default, platform-specific feedback is enabled.
Here is the only change with the prior PR!
Of course, I also add a test for this.

comments.body: Is there a reason for the PrimaryScrollController instead of just passing the scroll controller into the Scrollbar? Nothing wrong with it, just curious about the choice here.
Because both Scrollbar and ListView need to set controllers, it looks more intuitive to use PrimaryScrollController.
Makes sense, thanks!
